#Chennai, one of India’s largest cities, has had massive floods this week, inundating multi-lane highways, an airport runway, streets and homes. 
More than 40,000 people have been rescued in recent days after record rains lashed India's coastal state of Tamil Nadu, worsening weeks of flooding that has killed 269 people. (STRDEL/AFP/AFP/Getty Images)

#India #Chennaifloods

A little true story from recent #chennaifloods . . . .
This is how India is. While politics may try to differentiate people according to cast and relaigion, somehow Indians find a way to rise above all these petty discrimination and give humanity importance. A Hindu couple in Chennai, Mohan and his pregnant wife Chitra were stranded at their residence in Chennai during the torrential rains and flood that crippled the city recently. Chitra was also having labour pains and Mohan did not know how to take his wife to the hospital considering his neighbourhood was neck deep in water. Mohamed Yunus happen to spot the helpless couple and took them aboard a boat he was in. Not only did Yunus take them to the hospital but he also tried to ease the tensed couple by talking to them through out their journey. The couple have had a baby girl and as a token of thanks have decided to call her Yunus. Mohan even sent a text message to Yunus informing him about his decision. An elated Yunus shared the post on Facebook which has gone viral since.
#m_eye_nd

Just happened to speak to a friend in Bangalore and overheard her talking to her next door maid who had just received her salary for last month. And do you know what she had come to her for?? Here is her byte- 
So many of us think before donating 
So many of argue with house maids to come decide their salary 
So many of give them left over food 
So many of us don't trust them 
So many of make them a target when we misplace things 
Heard a door bell ring 
Surprised to see my neighbours maid standing with Rs 200
"Didi chennai bhej dena"
According to me she is the star donner 
Basanti mother of three kids works 5 houses to earn a living!

Thank you Seema Mishra Bhatnagar for sharing this! #Truehero #chennaifloods #kindness

Join us for Moving to Act, the third and final talk of our Re:Learn series, featuring writer, editor and award-winning columnist Krupa Ge.  Her brilliant first book on the 2015 Chennai floods, Rivers Remember,published by Context, an imprint of Westland, is out now to critical and popular acclaim. Ecologist and environmental studies scholar Dr Bharath Sundaram of Krea University will respond to the book and moderate the post-talk discussion. There will be a book signing after. 
Saturday August 3, 2019 | 5.30 pm
Krea University Chennai  Office

HEAVY RAIN ALERT IN CHENNAI #chennairains #chennaifloods #safety #chennairain #chennaiclimate #stayalert #rain #chennai

Chennai has been the center of ecological and planning related issues for as long as I could remember. As a child, I lived in a house opposite to a canal that went from clear to deep green to black - over a span of 10 years. I remember that when it rained, my mother would keep all the valuables in the loft. We used to pack up our necessities and move in with the upstairs neighbours temporarily, because we knew the canal would flood and the water would enter our house. Thinking back, it almost seems like a way of life for us. I had never given it much thought. I had never questioned why me and my family had to live through our house getting inundated every time it rained a little more than usual during monsoons. And how we’d line up outside the water lorry and fight for the last bucket of water during summer. Now older and hopefully wiser, I realise that the cause for these issues is the dire neglect of natural watersheds- The whole city has been planned on scattered bodies of water. This picture perfectly explains the consequences of that.
.
.

Posted @withrepost • @khubaibliophile Book Review | Rivers Remember | Krupa Ge | Non Fiction | .
"The (Chennai) floods didn't even spare the long dead." .
.
I picked up this timely and very important book for #bnbreadathon
.
.
Krupa Ge's book on #chennaifloods has become a timely read as another part of the country is right now struggling with flood. This book is a painstaking, methodical and in-depth scrutiny of the reasons behind these almost annual floods we face in some part of the country or the other. .
.
Most of us think that flood is a natural calamity. This book though paints a different picture. There are many reasons behind a flood that leaves hundreds of thousands of lives devastated. An absence or inadequacy of a disaster management program, haphazard "development" of cities, lack of urban planning, allocation of riverbeds and ponds for urban development, deforestation, climate change, apathy of the state, no contingency plans, and many more. 
The book also shares stories of victims and how everyone is affected in different ways with only one thing in common: loss. Loss of lives, livestock, property, income, relationships, business, careers, dreams and past struggles. .
.
.
While the book shares the stories of Chennai floods, while reading I was seeing the same stories unfolding somewhere in Assam. People struggling to find relatives, feed babies, find medicines and healthcare for the sick, old and pregnant women. Stray dogs, cats and other animals fighting for their lives. .
.
.
Take some time out to read this book to understand this calamity, because you don't have to live near a river or in a coastal area.The book also tells stories of empathy of common people and organisations that risk their lives to come out and help others. .
.
.
Some parts of the book feel too academic with a lot of statistics. But it only shows how well researched this book is. The book makes the magnitude of horrors of a flood real for the readers.
.
.
#assamese #assamfloods #helpassam #assam #chennairains #chennaifloods

Book#33 Rivers Remember by @krupage is one of those books that just sucks you in and takes you on the roller coaster that some of us (incl the author, friends & family) lived through....
.
.
I remember being out on the road with friends distributing, collecting, helping wherever we could... Sigh.. .
So far I have survived not one but two floods and am eternally grateful to all those who sent money/stuff and help... .
Do give this book a read .. .
.
#booksiread #books2019 #real #truth #water #chennaifloods #nightmares #womenauthor #bookstagram #lovereading #nonfiction

My book recommendation for this week: Rivers Remember, by Krupa Ge. A must read for any city dweller, especially for those who have battled the man-made disaster that 2015 floods were for Chennai. The book begins with an account of the deeply personal losses Krupa and family went through - that make us relive our experiences of that horrible week-long suffering. From the second chapter onwards, the book goes on to discuss the history of the city's water ways, its expansion in the past century, and takes a hard look at why it all happened the way it did - all backed by data points painstakingly gathered through RTI filings. The book also has a good number of anecdotes, especially the social media activism during crisis, various citizen initiatives, how the government handled it, and the way media covered it - in all of 200 odd pages. #Madras #Chennai #2015 #Floods #ChennaiFloods #manmadedisaster #contemporary #bookrecommendation  @ Odyssey Chennai

Although it is based on India but this message is for everyone who take showers instead of using taps, who wastes water.
It's for you to realize now how much water you waste.
Instead of cleaning vegetables under tap, wash it in a bucket of water.
Instead of leaving tap on while brushing, turn it off.
Turn on the tap, and shut off the shower.
#noshowerday 
#nsd
.
.
.
.
.
.
.
Thank you @twitter for sharing this message.
